comments.body: Shouldn't all build artifacts go in `build` for easier debugging?

This is the pattern that the current `flutter refresh` command uses. We may want to put more things into `build/`, and use a temp dir less often. I'd still want most of the build artifacts in `build/` to be semantic wrt to the user - something that they would understand and identify as useful to their project.
Maybe this error message should include info from `result.stderr`?
Is there any additional error information we should provide here? exitCode?

Perhaps we should change the contract for `getAdbDevices()` to throw an exception if we have an error listing devices? As a get method, we should be able to call it w/o side effects. Instead of printing an error here, that would likely be the responsibility of a caller of the method.

I'm not sure who calls getAdbDevices, where the best place to print the error would be, and which other callers would have to be made aware that getAdbDevices could now throw...

That was my initial thought as well and I considered throwing an exception. Looking at call sites for this method, I realized it's not really an exception, but rather additional information for the user. This method is used by higher level functions to gather information about devices, and this method (and others) are already calling `printError` as a sidecar way to provide additional information to the user.

That said, I agree that `printError` here (and elsewhere throughout this method and others) is not ideal in that it prevents calling methods from choosing how to present this additional information to the user.

Sorry, I didn't look at the rest of the impl of this method. It looks like we're already calling `printError()` here when we hit issues. Longer term we may want to instead return a more structured result from this method; definitely not necessary for this PR!
This `runCheckedSync` may mean that we don't get a spinner during the install. We'd need to change this to a async process call (and change the containing method signature to a Future result).
Correct. Will tackle in a subsequent PR.
Do these need to be printed?  Users can see them at any time by running logcat
I'm just being consistent with the existing behaviour: log messages that are ignored are still printed via printTrace. See the bottom of this function.
I added this yesterday. May have been a mistake. Feel free to remove that.
Throwing is nice here. +1
so this block is protected by an if statement but the similar block above isn't. I think you can get rid of the if statement here or is it possible to get an Observatory URI but not a Diagnostic URI?
Nevermind, I see that this is optional.
Is this function still used?
Yep, to write the SHA1 to the device during install. And we'll want to use that again, but correctly this time - #8295.

As we discussed, my understanding is this may be the wrong question for the tool to ask?

What changes our engine config is:
1.  Does the system have a GPU (if not, use --debug, software backend).
2.  Do we have a --release binary for this architecture (x86, x64, etc.) . If not force --debug.
That's why I filed and referenced #10248, which tracks that problem.  There are other places where we use the `isLocalEmulator` property though (like in analytics), so this was still worthwhile.

What we really want to check here is `isLocalEmulator`, right?  In a world where we support x86 physical devices (such devices do exist), we'll need to support release builds on them.

That said, it's complicated because our detection of whether the device is an emulator is best-effort (e.g. https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/10203)
Currently we don't support AOT compilation modes on x86/x64
Dart could support x64 if needed: https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/9253 however x86 AOT would be some months/weeks of work I'm told.
Why not always pass the target platform to the `BuildInfo`?
This is for scenarios where we don't know the target platform until we discover what kind of device is attached
`debuggingOptions` can legally be `null` here.
`assert(hostPort >= 0)`?
we don't guarantee that. We could audit all the call sites to make sure that the callers all check the range on the port, but as of right now we're depending on adb to do that.
Can we trust that `exception.message` will contain `adbPath`, or should we explicitly include that path in the error message here?

It does include it, but I'll test for that in the test to make sure it doesn't change.

The error looks like this in the wild:
```
Unable to run "adb", check your Android SDK installation and ANDROID_HOME environment variable: Cannot find executable for /usr/local/google/home/gspencer/Android/Sdk/platform-tools/adb.
```
What's the course of action for the user here?
Address one of the error messages that was printed out from `await AndroidApk.fromAndroidProject(project.android)`

Is there some way that we can mention that in the `throwToolExit` here?  Or some way we can assert that `AndroidApk.fromAndroidProject` reported some errors?  Perhaps have it `throwToolExit` with the errors instead of doing that here (maybe having an optional parameter like `{bool throwOnError = false}`?
Throwing in the factory would change the contract in a way that I don't really want for now

I'm curious why this `else` branch exists - at this point we've already gotten a valid hostPort. We just chose to fail if we then receive any stdout from `adb`?

We could instead just ignore stdout output.

I don't know for sure but I guess we're assuming if we get some unexpected output, it's could be a failure message (some tools write to `stdout`) and it's better to fail and review what's happened than assume that the port was mapping ok (which could result in harder to track down connection failures later in the process).
I don't see any mention of the stdout behavior in the adb docs. If this check is only based on observations, than updating it for new observations seem perfectly reasonable.

Yeah, I couldn't find any docs describing this (even casually in examples), so my guess is that it was based on how it seemed to work.

I still can't get my head around why Flutter doesn't get the stdout on macOS though, specifically in this case. I did try reading the ADB source code, but it's written in a language I don't speak.
The expected failure here is that you've specified an explicit port that's already used, so it can't be opened by `adb`.

I'm totally fine with this but we should phrase this as if it's by the whole team, not as if it's by one individual in the team. If someone really wants to track down who wrote it, they'll use git blame.
Previously this would exit, does the calling code handle null? Should we be doing a ToolExit here (and elsewhere?)
The documentation indicates that null is expected when there is no timestamp.
The calling code does handle null.
This should also catch `ProcessException` only, but that likely requires modifying `_runWithLoggingSync` in process.dart to throw a `ProcessException` instead of a `String`.
I filed #36242. What about we change exception type in a separate PR?
Sure, if you think that will make that change easier.
This looks strange to me. Why is the if sometimes multi-line and sometimes not?

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +574,578 @@      if (debuggingOptions.dumpSkpOnShaderCompilation)
        ...<String>['--ez', 'dump-skp-on-shader-compilation', 'true'],
      if (debuggingOptions.debuggingEnabled) ...<String>[
        if (debuggingOptions.buildInfo.isDebug) ...<String>[
          ...<String>['--ez', 'enable-checked-mode', 'true'],

comments.body: we shouldn't exclude non-flutter tags, otherwise we'll miss things like crash reports.
why are we removing the origin checking? this will make things like `flutter logs` display old logs.
this may be the cause of the regression, in fact...
this looks a lot simpler than the code used to look; why was the old code more complicated?
I'm not sure. I was trying to see in which version the `-T` flag was introduced.

Do we know anything about the situations where apiVersion is showing up as null?
Is something going wrong when the tool tries to run `adb getprop`, or is the `ro.build.version.sdk` property actually missing?

It's most likely that this property is just missing. If `adb getprop` had failed more severely, then the tool would not have gotten this far. In particular, it wouldn't have been able to figure out the `device.targetPlatform`:

https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/068fa84c5bb28382853a0506395158afa30f3cc6/packages/flutter_tools/lib/src/resident_runner.dart#L413

which boils down to a `getprop` call on Android:

https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/068fa84c5bb28382853a0506395158afa30f3cc6/packages/flutter_tools/lib/src/android/android_device.dart#L192
Can this be visibleForTesting?
Done
Is this a breaking change?
I think you can override `FutureOr<A> get a` with `A get a`, but I will double check
trivial nit: comment about adb exited earlier and it might be still streaming logs.
Done
Without this change its really hard to stop the log reader with mocked output from just passing everything though
I think there's only one more usage of this left, if you want to kill it.
Theres a few more...
Was this change necessary for the fix?

Per adb specs, the `-T` has to be followed with either plain number or quoted timestamp.
And it does fail for me otherwise.
We could also run `adb shell pm list users` for them to list possible users

We could it for them, but I don't want to parse the output since there's no machine readable format options and this I doubt this flag will be used except by users who are already familiar with Android and `adb` (see b/142944798).
```
$ adb shell pm list users       

Users:
	UserInfo{0:Owner:13} running
	UserInfo{10:jane:10} running
```
I don't think launching will work if the user isn't running (though install will?) and I don't want particularly want to explain all that.
Makes sense!
thank you
thank you again
eventually this should be passed as an argument or injected, but I did not want to refactor all of the device types at once
SGTM
This logic is the same as _installLatestApp, just un-nested.
This is the same as the old `installApp`
Cache this validity check, since it turns out the android device was performing it twice on every run.
